locutie.beschrijving: A historical and theological exploration of the figure of Elijah as the bridge between the Old and New Testaments, linking ancient miracles to the hope of Advent.
locutie.exegetische_kwaliteit: High. The preacher connects Malachi, Luke, and Matthew to build a biblical-theological trajectory of 'newness'.

illocutie.beschrijving: Primarily asserting the continuity of God's work through the figure of Elijah to encourage a posture of hope.
voorbeelden: I will give you a little background material.
He is the embodiment of the best hopes of Israel.
We are the ones who believe that God is making new.

perlocutie.beoogd_effect: To move the hearer from despair/cynicism to a state of expectant waiting (Advent).
perlocutie.pneumatologisch_bewustzijn: Low. The Spirit is mentioned in a quote (Luke 1:17) but not as the active agent of the current sermon-event.

voorbeelden: He appeared in an ancient time.
He is the carrier of our best hopes.
Pause in the frenzy to make space.
Remember that the Jews at Passover set a place.
I do not care if you spend Advent in a frenzy.
Someone who has promised to come... will.
commissieven.kwaliteit: Weak. The promises are mostly reported as third-person facts rather than first-person divine commitments delivered 'now'.

voorbeelden: We proclaim the Lord’s death until he comes.
declaratieven.autoriteit: Low. The preacher describes the act of proclamation rather than performing a transformative declaration (e.g., 'Your sins are forgiven').

indicatoren: Repetitive 'He is not done yet' (Section II) functions as a description of potential rather than a current act.
Talking about what 'we believe' instead of what God is doing.
constatief_surplus_analyse.effect_op_hoorder: The hearer becomes an observer of a theological idea rather than a participant in a divine encounter.

voorbeelden: Someone who has promised to come... will.

tweede_persoon.gebruik: Limited. Used for 'You cannot understand' or 'If you are rational'.

derde_persoon.gebruik: Dominant. Talking about Elijah, Jesus, the Jews, and the world.

foutief_patroon.beschrijving: Assertive (History of Elijah) -> Assertive (Theology of Hope) -> Directive (Pause/Remember).
voorbeelden: Section I & II (Assertive) leads directly to the final paragraph's 'Pause in the frenzy' (Directive).
foutief_patroon.probleem: The imperative to 'hope' or 'pause' is not preceded by a performative act of grace that enables it.

voorbeelden_slechte_verhouding: Because we believe... we celebrate... so pause.

diagnostische_evaluatie.diagnose_toelichting: The sermon functions as a brilliant lecture on biblical typology and the concept of hope, but it remains 'about' God and Elijah rather than being an 'event' of God's Word.

sterke_punten.tekstueel_bewijs: The connection between Elijah's miracles and Jesus' ministry.
sterke_punten.effect: Provides a strong intellectual framework for Advent.

zwakke_punten.tekstueel_bewijs: The heavy use of 'He' and 'They' instead of 'You'.
zwakke_punten.probleem: Keeps the gospel at arm's length.

diagnostische_evaluatie.gebeuren_toelichting: It is a 'talk about' an event rather than the event itself.
diagnostische_evaluatie.sacramentele_toelichting: Lacks the 'Toezegging' (Promise) that binds God to the hearer in the present moment.

openbaringsleer.god_als_spreker: No. God is the object of the sermon, not the subject speaking through it.
openbaringsleer.prediker_als_mandataris: Weak. The preacher acts as a teacher/guide rather than a herald.
tekstueel_bewijs: I will give you a little background material.

pneumatologie.perlocutie_theologie: Implicitly assumes that explaining the text will produce hope.
tekstueel_bewijs: With the spirit and power of Elijah (quoting Luke).

sacramentstheologie.preek_als_genademiddel: No. The sermon is a preparation for the meal, not a meal in itself.
tekstueel_bewijs: That is why we eat and drink this meal.

aanbevelingen.werkwoord_audit_samenvatting: Shift from 'He did' and 'We believe' to 'God does' and 'I promise you'.

specifieke_suggesties.huidige_formulering: Elijah is the assurance... that God has not abandoned us.
specifieke_suggesties.voorgestelde_revisie: Hear this word from God: I have not abandoned you, and I will not leave you in your deathliness.
specifieke_suggesties.verschil: Moves from a theological fact to a personal promise (Commissive).

toezegging_versterking.probleem: The promise is buried in a description of what Jews and early Christians believed.
toezegging_versterking.suggestie: Directly announce the 'newness' to the congregation.
voorbeeldzinnen: Today, in this room, God is turning your heart.

adressering_verbetering.suggestie: Use 'You' to implicate the hearer in the scarcity and the coming abundance.
voorbeeldzinnen: You are the widow whose oil will not run dry.

indicatief_imperatief_herstel.probleem: The call to 'pause' is a work the hearer must do.
indicatief_imperatief_herstel.suggestie: Make the 'pause' a gift of the promise.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: The sermon is intellectually stimulating and biblically rich, but it requires a shift into the performative mode to truly become an 'Advent event'.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_schulz_von_thun: SvT would focus on the preacher's 'self-revelation' of cheating on the lectionary; SAT focuses on the failure to use the 'Declarative' key to change the hearer's reality.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retoriek: Rhetorically, the 'He is not done yet' refrain is powerful; illocutionarily, it remains an Assertive (stating a fact) rather than a Commissive (God binding Himself).
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_SAT: SAT reveals that despite the 'high' theology, the sermon remains 'constative' because it talks about God's power without exercising the mandate to speak on God's behalf.

kernzinnen_analyse.effectiviteit: Moderate; builds anticipation but doesn't deliver the presence.
High, but weakened by being framed as a historical quote.

appendices.notities: The preacher uses the 'we' pronoun to soften the distance, but it often results in a 'talking about our shared ideas' rather than 'God addressing you'.
